caption_original:
Have you ever heard of Kicking Horse Pass NHS? As part of the development of the Canadian Pacific railway, this site played a key role in connecting Canadians to each other and the world! 

Did you know? You can still see parts of the original route that the Canadian Pacific railway used in the 1880s in parts of the Trans-Canada highway today! #DYK Yoho National Park

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

caption_original:
Did you know the Massasauga Rattlesnakeüêç is one of Canada's most unusual snakes and one of the most threatened! This solitary, passive and timid rattlesnake relies on camouflage to avoid detection, shaking its tail in warning when it feels threatened.

Preferring flight to confrontation, it rarely strikes, doesn't pursue people and doesn't always inject venom when it bites. #WildlifeWednesday

caption_original: Happy International Archaeology Day! Underwater archaeological excavation at Red Bay National Historic Site began in 1978. Four well-preserved 16th century Basque whaling galleons and four small whaling craft have been found, making it one of the most significant marine archaeological finds in North America. This UNESCO World Heritage Site is also where you might find our most unique red chair view! #IAD2017 @ArchaeologyDay

This UNESCO World Heritage Site is also where you might find our most unique red chair view!

Today marks the beginning of Women‚Äôs History Month! There are many incredible women who have been designated National Historic Persons, including Carrie Matilda Derick. 

She was the first woman to attain the rank of professor at a Canadian university. This pioneer in the field of genetics attained international recognition as a botanist and made an outstanding contribution to both academic and popular science: ow.ly/zVn830fsOEt

Stay tuned for more historic women on our social media channels! Women in Canada

caption_original:
Happy Halloween! Did you know it‚Äôs also the last day of Bat Week??

As part of a landscape restoration project at Georgian Bay Islands National Park, staff needed to find out if bats were taking up residence in an old maintenance shed. The park‚Äôs Resource Conservation team used an ultrasonic acoustic detector and found Little Brown Bats sleeping in the building. They were able to determine exactly when the bats moved out in the fall, so while the bats were away for winter vacation down south, staff installed 'bat boxes' all around the area so they had nice new homes to move into when they returned in the spring. #BatWeek
